utterances: And of course for television this is really bad news because you're going to disrupt the pilot season.
And you're going to be throwing a lot of reruns at people who may get quickly bored.
And so what are you projecting in terms of the financial fallout?
Well, it's hard to say.
The last strike was 1988, and the economic impact there, lost wages, was about $500 million.
The industry was much smaller then.
But this could disrupt a lot of things.
It's going to be tough for members of the Writers Guild, especially the people who are trying to break into the field.
And it could change the face of broadcast television as we know it.
Five hundred million, though, that's what we've already lost.
We've already lost that.
And it's - well, if you look at what's going on.
You have 52 scripted shows that production has ceased on.
The shows are much more elaborate.
A lot of other things going on.
So the industry is much larger in the scheme of things than it was in 1988.
But when the strike was over, everything bounced right back very quickly.
Jack, thank you.
You're welcome.
That's Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
We hope most of you have already made it to your Thanksgiving destination.
Some people though may still be delayed, or even worse stuck in an airport.
Well, here's a silver lining.
You don't have to skip a delicious meal if you're at an airport.
That's according to Joe Brancatelli.
He writes about business travel for Portfolio.com, and he joins me now.
Hi, Joe.
Hello, Madeleine.
Happy Thanksgiving.
Thank you.
Well, I really can't believe it.
You actually found good airport food?
It is shocking.

In light of the terrible conditions we all know about travel these days, one of the few bright spots is that dining at the airport has really improved dramatically in the last few years, partially because they know people are spending more time at airports, so they figure they can hit you up for more money if they improve the dining experience.
So the industry has created a piece of jargon for it.

It's called dwell time at the airport, in the point of you might show up two to three hours before your flight because you never know what's happening with the security or anything else, and of course in the perfect world you've flown through security and you're sitting there with two hours to do nothing before your flight across the country with no food, so you go looking for something to eat.
Well, let's talk about some of your faves.
You recently wrote a list of various restaurants in various airport terminals.
Give us the top five.
Oh, gee, the top five.
Well, that - I'm big on local food.
The people who handle the master concessions at the airports have gone to local restaurateurs and said put a branch in our airport.

So for example, in a place Houston, you can eat in a place called Pappadeaux Seafood Kitchen, which is probably one of the best seafood restaurants in the South, and you will get fresh oysters, the kind...
Fresh oysters?
No.
Fresh oysters at an airport.
It is a rare and thrilling treat.
In a place like Phoenix there are two branches of the Blue Burrito Grill, which is just a terrific Southwest-style Mexican food.
The food is fresh, and it's also lower in calories than, you know, going to a Burger King or McDonalds.
And I noticed on your list - this made me chuckle a little bit - San Francisco actually has sushi?
San Francisco has a place called Ebisu, which is a branch of one of the best sushi places in San Francisco.
And actually, San Francisco - it shouldn't surprise anyone - has really spared no expense to bring in some of the best names in the San Francisco dining scene.
And it needn't be fancy.

I mean if you come to Washington, there's a chain called Five Guys, which is a burger and hotdog and french fry place, but you know, the burgers are hand-formed and the meat is never frozen, so you could still get a great burger at the airport if that's what you're looking for.
That's former Vice President Francisco Santos.
He's also the cousin of President Juan Manuel Santos, the chief architect of the peace process.
Francisco Santos complains that under the agreement, guerrillas who carried out massacres and kidnappings can avoid prison as long as they tell the truth about their atrocities.
They might not go to jail for a second.
They don't ask for forgiveness.
They haven't said, you know, we're sorry for killing and displacing and kidnapping and terrorism.
Voters will have the final say in an October 2 plebiscite.
For the peace treaty to take effect, the yes vote must outnumber the no vote by a simple majority.
Maria Victoria Llorente is a Bogota political analyst.
I think that the peace agreement, peacebuilding in Colombia, needs a huge endorsement, a very big yes.
That, she says, would strengthen the Santos government as it builds roads and schools in former war zones and brings demobilized rebels back into civilian life.
Most polls show the yes vote ahead, but one survey this month predicted voters would reject the peace accord.
That probably would not mean a return to fighting, but Llorente says it could derail post-war reconstruction.
If the no wins, the next government may say, you know, well, that was the past government.
It isn't, you know, an agreement that I really think it's important, so I can - I'll change my mind and I'll do something different.
To prevent that, the government has launched emotional spots on TV and social media.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Speaking Spanish).
This one proclaims, ""in places where bombs once exploded we will celebrate life."" Here in Bogota, peace activists are discussing how to get out the vote.
One of them is Lorena Murcia.
(Speaking Spanish).
She says rebel family members convinced her to join the FARC guerrillas when she was only 10.
She later deserted.
Now 23, Murcia says a yes vote is the way to prevent further bloodshed.
(Speaking Spanish).
She says, ""I don't want other kids to go off to war like I had to.
I'm going to vote yes because I want the FARC to disappear."" For NPR News, I'm John Otis in Bogota, Colombia.
Now let's take a break from politics and big judicial decisions to talk about a pilot's unprecedented flight across the Atlantic.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
He made it.
Charles A.
Lindbergh landed at Le Bourget Airport in Paris.
No, wrong tape.
No, no. Not the right one.
Sorry, not that transatlantic flight.
We're talking about Bertrand Piccard.
He's one of the pilots of the Solar Impulse 2, which is trying to make it all the way around the world using solar power.
If it succeeds, this would be the first flight around the world in a plane powered only by the sun.
The long trip has been split up into lots of separate flights.
The transatlantic part of the trip was the 15th leg - one of the longest flights - and risky because it meant three days and nights over an ocean with no fuel.
Piccard set off from New York on Monday and landed successfully in southern Spain this morning.
Good morning, Sevilla.
(APPLAUSE)
He was handed a bottle of champagne and spoke to a crowd gathered on the tarmac.
The Atlantic has always been the symbol of going from the old world to the new world.
And everybody has tried to cross the Atlantic with sailboats, steamboats, balloons.
Today, it's a solar-powered airplane for the first time ever, flying electric with no fuel and no pollution.
